thread.title: Multnomah County OKs loan for nonprofit to buy closed strip club
thread.title_full: Multnomah County OKs loan for nonprofit to buy closed strip club | OregonLive.com

author: Tony Hernandez | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Multnomah County OKs loan for nonprofit to buy closed strip club
text:
A single black heel discarded by an exotic dancer inside a closed strip club rested on a lime green center stage as the executive director of a nonprofit discussed plans Thursday to purchase and convert the venue into a 24-hour family shelter with the help of Multnomah County taxpayer dollars.
Meanwhile, the Urban League of Portland plans to request the same type of deal the county gave Portland-based Human Solutions, Inc. , an official told commissioners on Thursday.
Human Solutions received its unanimous OK from the Board of Commissioners to receive $697,697 that includes a $300,000 loan for a down payment for the closed strip club building. The remaining money, most of it county dollars, will pay for renovations that will remove the bar, private dance areas, add more toilets, fix up the commercial kitchen and add laundry facilities, said Human Solutions Executive Director Andy Miller .
Human Solutions director explains meaning of vice to nice Andy Miller, director of hHuman Solutions Inc., discuss plans to convert a closed strip club into a homeless shelter.
"From vice to nice," he said about transforming the closed Black Cauldron building located at 16015 S.E. Stark St. into a use that's received support by neighborhood groups. Residents and neighborhoods don't normally support the opening of a homeless shelter in their area, he said.
In exchange for the $300,000 loan, the nonprofit agrees to operate the shelter for at least six years, a service valued at $50,000 annually, according to loan paperwork . If the nonprofit backs out or the county chooses another contractor, the county has dibs to take over the property and keep the shelter running.
For seven years, Human Solutions has typically provided shelter services for families during the winter season, Miller said. Instead of finding a property to lease only for the winter season, the unexpected option to purchase the property allows for year-round operations.
If completed by February, the shelter should house up to 130 individuals a day, Miller said. That's up from a capacity of about 100 in years past, he said.
Urban League of Portland President and CEO Nkenge Harmon Johnson said she was excited for Human Solutions. The Urban League has seen homeless and poor populations, especially among African Americans, who have been pushed out into eastern areas of the county from gentrification, she said. It's an area her organization plans to serve as well, she said.
"I am also excited for the opportunity for the Urban League to come before you in the months to come with a similar opportunity," she said. "When it's our turn to say we've got this deal, this package, we want to bring together to purchase property that will allow us to better serve the community that we serve."
Her comments came moments after Multnomah County Commissioner Loretta Smith warned that this deal was made outside the public process.
"I do have a problem with us setting up a nonprofit and giving them an asset that is theirs," Smith said. "I would have much preferred us buy the project, and they lease it back. That would have been a better tool."
The county plans, by June 30, 2016, to begin seeking qualified nonprofits to provide the various homeless services for the next five years. Smith said the deal means that county staff could be pressured to recommend Human Solutions to keep its contract.
Miller said if the county chooses another nonprofit for the services at the Stark Street location, it would lease the property to another nonprofit to use the facility.
The half-acre property contains the 7,438-square-foot building currently owned by JZ Property Management in Lake Oswego, according to PortlandMaps.com, a website of the City of Portland. Its market value stands at $1.2 million, according to the website. Officials have said the purchase price is about $1 million.
Mary Li, director of the county's Community Services Division, said past family shelters in the area haven't been suitable for large numbers of families. They have lacked sufficient kitchens or other basic amenities that a shelter should have.
But the building needs a lot of work.
Walking into the closed club, it's certainly suited for October and Halloween with paintings of warlocks and scantily clad witches and fairies adorning the walls. Liquor bottles were left on the bar, used pots and pans in the kitchen. Clothes and undergarments, and heels, were left in the dressing room.
Chairwoman Deborah Kafoury said officials at the city of Gresham were happy with the county's steps to put the building "into the community's hands instead of having it be a place where women are victimized."
